review_title: They want to be known as a great employer, without actually BEING a great employer.
pros: Campus is pretty. Brunswick is nice.
cons: Their new "wfh/hybrid" policy is in name only. They are stuck in the dark ages and do not support remote work, even for positions that can do their work from home, even for positions who have successfully done their work from home. Lots of turnover at the upper level (president is leaving after short tenure). There is not only no support for "hourly" or support staff, but active contempt for us. If. you're faculty, maybe it's nice. For the rest of us: demoralizing. And they string us along, claiming they want to make things better or that they're taking steps to make things better, and then either they don't, or they actually make things worse. They pay lip service to being eco-friendly, but its at the cost of employee environment (ex: turn off a/c and fans during heat waves).

job_title: Head Resident Assistant in Brunswick, ME
pros: Flexible schedule, Understanding professional staff, adequate training
cons: Head Resident Assistant role requires more time management and mental capacity than a proctor or RA role.

review_title: High Level of Politics and Low Morale
pros: Lovely campus, wonderful, well chosen student body.
cons: Highly political environment, much more so than other academia environments I've experienced. A lacking attention to workplace harmony, erratic and poor decision making by executives and overall low morale.

pros: Smartest, kindest, best colleagues I've ever had. Wise leadership. Interesting, bright, diverse students who care about each other and about making the world better. Well-resourced and prestigious college that values its people. Benefits, salary, work environment unparalleled . Maine is also an amazing and beautiful place to live.
cons: The flip side to being a great place to work is that turnover tends to be low. People get in jobs and stay so it may be harder to find the "next job" in your career journey. But that should not be a deterrent to working here because Bowdoin is an outstanding employer.

review_title: Diversity is a show/  Very Weak school
job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Brunswick, ME
pros:
1- Newer facilities
2- Maine is beautiful in September.
cons:
The following are based on my honest feelings, experience, and interaction with students.

1- Tenured faculty delegate their duties to others, for example, pressuring non-tenured faculty to research with students. At the same time, they do not work with students for obvious reasons, the lack of research projects. 

3- Weak faculty members in their fields of research, the majority of faculty members were graduated from Ivey League schools, but they were not at the top of their class. Most of them with their current C.V cannot secure an academic job in R1 or R2 schools. For example, an associate professor who published nine papers in very weak journals in his 15-20 years of academic life, judging applicants with much stronger research. 

2- Few students disclosed their traumatic experiences that some tenured faculty discourage underrepresented students such as women, Hispanics, Latin, and black from pursuing a STEM career. 

3- Students spend high tuition fees for very weak curriculums. One can look at the outcome of GRE subject test scores of their best students. Looking into courses, one can easily see that the courses touch the surface of topics.

4- One of my worse decision in my life. They respect you up to accepting the job; get ready to hear unwelcoming comments about your rank by tenured faculty. I was told, "if visiting assistant professors were good, they would get a tenure-track job, not a VAP position."

5- The teaching load for VAPs is 2-2, but usually, they assign 4-credit hours courses to VAPs. Classes are typically full of students with an average of 30-40 enrollments. On the other hand, there are "artificial" caps for courses taught by faculty. The hard work gets done by VAPs, but faculty members get the benefits.

6- The worst weather ever.

Your sessions can sometimes run late while helping students so good time and work management skills will be needed. You'll be working part-time as a student (just a few hours every week) so the pay isn't substantial at all.

review_title: Pay for staff positions are not competitive
pros: Immediate supervisors and co-workers are good. Benefits are good
cons:
Bowdoin College does not pay staff a livable wage. Starting pay for a groundskeeper is $14.00 dollars. The majority of the staff have side jobs just to pay bills. Students at the college gathered signatures to raise the minimum wage for staff. The college in response agreed to raise the minimum wage to $17.00 dollars an hour by the end of 2021. In March of 2020 the college informed staff that the minimum will not be raised until further notice.
Bowdoin College is a good place to work if you already have money, your spouse has a well paying job, your in upper managment, or your a professor.

review_title: Potentially great, but be careful of the department you are hired into
pros: Good benefits. One of few larger, stable employers in the midcoast region. Has a nice gym, for what that's worth.
cons:
I've witnessed terrible management here. Department managers receive no managerial training nor are they reviewed in any routine way. If you department is poorly managed, it unfortunately will not improve. I previously worked at educational institutions as well as other non-profits and Fortune 500s, and Bowdoin is the first place I've worked that's placed absolutely no emphasis on talent management or development. There is a fairly substantial waste of resources as well as completely arcane (and inefficient) staff hiring, support and advancement.

I hope that there are departments here that are well managed - and I do believe there are - but it seems that it's luck of the draw. For all of Bowdoin's hopes to become more fiscally efficient with its staffing, it's wasting untold resources on untalented individuals. 

Lastly, there's money to be had at Bowdoin, but it's incredibly strangely dispersed (not necessarily by merit, influence or skill set value) and most staff positions receive fairly low salaries when compared to industry standards. If you want to receive fair compensation, negotiate hard up front. I haven't heard of legitimate pay increases once you're in the works here, though I'm sure there are exceptions to the rule.

job_title: Circulation Desk Assistant in Brunswick, ME
pros: Can get coursework done during shift.
cons: I've loved every minute of it.

review_title: Took me a while to warm up to Bowdoin but now I love it
pros: Flexible environment, you get out what you put into it. Bowdoin provides the resources so that you can do some really amazing things if you set your mind to it. Being surrounded by incredibly intelligent people is a huge plus - every single person that got into the school brings something unique to the table. Tightknit community that provides many connections for job opportunities. Professors are awesome for the most part and will always give you individual attention if you seek it out.
cons: Administration has seemed harsh and out of touch the past couple of years. Not the most socially gratifying school.. If you're looking to go to a place with a huge party every weekend Bowdoin is not the place for you. Can seem too small at times, but hey, it is what you make it. Obviously the weather during the winter sucks

pros: flexible schedule, good health benefits and retirement. Top-notch students that predominately want to learn and are engaged in the learning process. Bowdoin is very good at supplying us with the materials we need in order to teach cutting edge laboratories.
cons: the work schedule is "Boom Bust" some days no breaks all day. some days are 11 hours long and the pay scale is about 50-60% of what a visiting professor gets and a lot of the time laboratory instructors have to work a lot harder when teamed up with a visiting faculty member.

review_title: Great place for faculty, not so for staff
pros: The benefits are excellent—especially the retirement benefits. Employees also have access to a beautiful campus with lots of amenities.  It's an especially great place if you have kids: access to the sports facilities, camps for kids during school vacation weeks, performances, museums, etc.
cons: The senior administration is very weak-there is no vision or understanding about what a liberal arts college is all about, instead they have created a corporate atmosphere.  They do not respect the administrative or support staff as professionals. There is no serious recognition of the staffs' accomplishments or contributions to the college—the administration's only attempts at this are to hold a summer picnic with prizes such as coupons and a holiday lunch. The Human Resources Department seems to focus on firing employees rather than supporting them.

pros: Bowdoin College is a fantastic place with fantastic people, and giving tours of it is a ton of fun. $10 per tour, but the real reward is the EXPERIENCE.
cons: Sometimes you just finished a paper that you stayed up all night completing and then you have to give a tour in the morning, and that kind of sucks. But if you tell the tour guides assigned to the same slot as you all of this they will generally be sympathetic and take out that day's tour or tours, as long as there aren't so many people that you're also needed. Also the Admissions Office has free coffee for everyone all the time.

pros: The office culture is supportive and focused while still maintaining a fun atmosphere. Whether you work in the administrative office or in a different capacity, as an undergraduate student, this office is an ideal place to spend multiple hours a week getting a taste for the professional side of how colleges are run.
cons: There are truly not many cons when working with the Bowdoin College office of Admissions. Fair hours, fair pay for an undergrad, and a wonderful office culture all contribute to this being a great place to work.

review_title: Good opportunity for student employment on campus

cons: While the pay is great, dining hall jobs are the least desired because you're constantly doing stuff and there's no time do other stuff like schoolwork.

pros: As a student at Bowdoin College I find it is a pleasant place. All employees are great and usually friendly.
cons: The cold weather can be miserable. At times there is five feet of snow on the sides of the paths.

review_title: Not my dream job, but still a great place to work
job_title: Casual Kitchen Staff in Brunswick, ME
pros: great work environment/culture, understanding coworkers
cons: the students we clean up after. 99% of them are great, but there are always the troublemakers who seem to make it their purpose in life to make the lives of those around them more difficult. Pretty par for the course for any food services job, as far as I can tell.

pros: Pretty campus. Free software like office, but that's about it. Benefits WERE good a few years ago.
cons:
If you're upper management your golden but anything lower is pretty bad pay wise and treatment wise. For example there was a busy hallway and the kids all wanted to through the boxes at the end of the stairs. I saw it as a tripping hazard and made a rather large box and labeled it "please put cardboard here" so its less of a hazard and easy to clean. Well the bosses at the time saw it as a bad idea and said they are suppose to through them away in the other building. Well they weren't and a few times people tripped going up stairs so I made that decision to do it anyways because I didn't want to see anyone get hurt nor did I want to get hurt. Well that was one of many things that lead to my unemployment. The business practice is SO bad that they have to tell people to hide OSHA violations. Rather than welcoming them in the building they have to come announced because they don't want to get charged. LL bean welcomes them. Bowdoin here doesn't. 

benis are going down. if u made 20,000 or under they hand you a benefits card of $350. That was 2014. 2015 came around and went down to $300 and the co pay went from $10 to $20. 2016 they wanted $275 for that card and then 2017 wanted to eliminate that card that helps pay for all this crap. So health care is becoming more expensive over there and people are a lot less happy.

free software is good and they say you can get operating systems from them for free. Office you can but they never give you the operating systems when you request them. 5 times i put in for it and no one ever got back to me nor in person.

Also I received a very threatening message from a spouse of one of my former bosses over there. I took it to the police as this threat was directed at me and my family. I don't know what I did to tick this guy off but its one of the many reasons to now carry a gun around. I do not take threats lightly. So anyone who says they are treated well here, I don't know what you are talking about. 

No one matters unless your upper management. They don't care for anyone over there even if you have a documented disability like I did. Oh and by the way if you don't appear on camera for 2 hours they fire you.

Anything with Bowdoin written on it is expensive so values I guess you can say are high.
